title: Public housing estates in Shek Kip Mei
text:
Public housing estates in Shek Kip Mei are <a href="public%20housing">public housing</a> in an area originally known as <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei">Kap Shek Mi</a> in <a href="New%20Kowloon">New Kowloon</a> on the North Eastern <a href="Kowloon%20Peninsula">Kowloon Peninsula</a> of <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>.
History.
Hong Kong's public housing program was initiated by Governor <a href="Alexander%20Grantham">Alexander Grantham</a> following <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei%20Fire">a major fire</a> on 25 December 1953. The Shek Kip Mei area was the location of tens of thousands of makeshift homes of <a href="immigrant">immigrant</a>s from <a href="Mainland%20China">Mainland China</a>. The fire cost many lives, and left 53,000 people homeless.
The <a href="public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing</a> program introduced "multi story building" with fire- and flood-proof construction. The clearance of the fire debris and demolition of the remaining makeshift houses paved the way for construction of the <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei%20Estate">Shek Kip Mei Low-cost Housing Estate</a> (石硤尾廉租屋邨).
Chak On Estate.
Chak On Estate () is a <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing estate</a> in <a href="Tai%20Wo%20Ping">Tai Wo Ping</a>, Shek Kip Mei. Formerly Tai Wo Ping Cottage Area () and built at a <a href="hill">hill</a> near <a href="Lung%20Cheung%20Road">Lung Cheung Road</a>, the estate consists of 4 residential blocks completed in 1983.
Nam Shan Estate.
Nam Shan Estate () is a <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing estate</a> in Shek Kip Mei, located near <a href="Tai%20Hang%20Tung%20Estate">Tai Hang Tung Estate</a>, <a href="Tai%20Hang%20Sai%20Estate">Tai Hang Sai Estate</a> and <a href="Yau%20Yat%20Tsuen">Yau Yat Tsuen</a>. It was formerly called "<a href="Kowloon%20Tsai">Kowloon Tsai</a>". It comprises 8 residential blocks built in 1977.
Pak Tin Estate.
Pak Tin Estate () is a <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing estate</a> in Shek Kip Mei, located between <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei%20Estate">Shek Kip Mei Estate</a> and <a href="Chak%20On%20Estate">Chak On Estate</a>. It is currently the largest public housing estate in Shek Kip Mei.
Shek Kip Mei Estate.
Shek Kip Mei Estate (<a href="Chinese%20language">Chinese</a>: 石硤尾邨) is the first <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing estate</a> in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a>. The estate was constructed as a result of a fire in <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei">Shek Kip Mei</a> in 1953, to settle the families of inhabitants in the <a href="squatter">squat</a>s over the hill who lost their homes in one night.
Tai Hang Tung Estate.
Tai Hang Tung Estate () is a <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20Hong%20Kong">public housing estate</a> in Shek Kip Mei, located near <a href="Tai%20Hang%20Sai%20Estate">Tai Hang Sai Estate</a> and <a href="Nam%20Shan%20Estate">Nam Shan Estate</a>.
Tai Hang Sai Estate.
Tai Hang Sai Estate () is a <a href="private%20housing%20estate">private housing estate</a> in Shek Kip Mei, located between <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei%20Estate">Shek Kip Mei Estate</a> and <a href="Tai%20Hang%20Tung%20Estate">Tai Hang Tung Estate</a>, near <a href="MTR">MTR</a> <a href="Shek%20Kip%20Mei%20station">Shek Kip Mei station</a>. It consists of 8 <a href="residential%20building">residential building</a>s which were built in 1965 and 1977 respectively. The estate was built and managed by a <a href="privately%20owned%20company">privately owned company</a> called "Hong Kong Settlers Housing Corporation Limited" ().
